Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Use of Digital Technologies by Indigenous People for Communication Within and Beyond Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The use of information and communication technologies by indigenous people has opened new opportunities for these marginalized groups to communicate across geographic distances and to influence policy and decision making. This doctoral dissertation research project will investigate the capacity of the Internet to facilitate productive dialogue among indigenous peoples, scientists and government agencies. The project will provide new insights into how digital interactions produce empowerment as well as inequalities for the various stakeholders involved. Project findings have the potential to provide new insights regarding how vulnerable groups might better leverage digital technologies to empower themselves as well as how different stakeholders might collaborate with one another and with policymakers across cultural, epistemological, and bureaucratic barriers in a search for solutions to changing environmental conditions. The doctoral student will work with local Inuit communities in northern Canada, but these issues affect marginalized populations globally, and the project will provide insights into the Internet as a forum for enabling international dialogue and decision making in a diverse set of locales in the U.S. and elsewhere. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The project will address three core questions: (1) How are environmental change issues articulated online? (2) Are such digital discourses shaped and constrained by current policies and do they affect the ways in which the Inuit engage with such policies? (3) What are the technological and discursive attributes of the Web that contribute to these constraints? The doctoral student will use a combination of topic modeling and critical discourse analysis to explore these questions and provide an understanding of the discursive framework with which the Inuit must engage. He also will analyze the experiences of Inuit as they engage with digital spaces as well as how cultural and epistemological aspects of digital technologies may prevent them from being fully engaged. The research has implications for the theoretical and policy-based understanding of digital technologies, the engagement of technologies by indigenous and marginalized peoples, and the communication of environmental information and knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is the first project to systematically examine how the Internet is being used by indigenous communities in the Arctic to discuss environmental management. Inuit, an indigenous people that span the Arctic regions of the US, Canada, Russia, and Greenland, are struggling with many environmental shifts related to climate change. The project evaluated the ability of the Internet to empower Inuit by producing digital spaces in which they can contribute indigenous knowledge to discussions of environmental policy. The project asked how Arctic environmentalism is being discussed online; whether these digital discussions incorporate indigenous views; and how different attributes of the Web contribute to the representation of different knowledge systems. In addition to providing insights into the cultural biases of the Internet, this project sought to improve understandings of how the Internet can be used by marginalized communities in response to environmental changes and problems.

NSF funding allowed Co-PI Jason Young to carry out multiple research methods to answer these questions. First, he collected approximately 3600 different Web pages, across 15 different websites and social media platforms, that discussed the Arctic environment. He developed an innovative research methodology, combining computational analysis and qualitative methods, to analyze how these pages discussed the Arctic environment and whether they incorporated indigenous perspectives. Based on this analysis he produced a model describing the full range of topics being discussed across the Web sites, the relationship between discussions of Western science and indigenous knowledge, and the techniques used to justify particular perspectives on environmental policy. This research gave him initial ideas as to how digital discussions constrain cross-cultural dialogue. Second, this funding allowed him to travel to the Inuit community of Igloolik, Nunavut for 10 weeks, where he interviewed adult Inuit about their use of the Internet and their participation in online discussions of the environment. These interviews gave him additional insights into how Inuit are participating in Web-based environmental discussions, as well as whether they feel that these discussions exclude important knowledge about the Arctic. Based on this research, the project made the following conclusions:

  1. Digital discussions of the Arctic environment are highly stratified. In other words, different views and perspectives of the Arctic tend to remain separate from one another. The most popular websites that I examined tended to focus on scientific discussions of the Arctic, or on economic development in the region. Indigenous discussions are less common and primarily found on sites run by indigenous organizations. This means that the Internet has not been very successful at facilitating cross-cultural dialogue about Arctic environmental management.
  2. The lack of digital infrastructure in the Arctic is a major constraint for indigenous participation. The lack of a robust infrastructure means that Internet is very expensive, that Internet speeds are very slow, and that Inuit cannot access the Internet when they are traveling, camping, or hunting. These factors not only make the Internet less accessible for all Inuit, but they make it particularly difficult for hunters and elders to make use of the Internet. Since these are the individuals most likely to possess indigenous knowledge, this greatly reduces the possibility of productive contributions of this knowledge to ongoing environmental discussions.
  3. Cultural biases are also a major constraint for indigenous participation. The prevalence of written English, the widespread adoption of scientific practices (such as citing published material, rather than drawing on oral traditions), the underrepresentation of quotations from Inuit, and a range of other digital social norms and knowledge politics all minimized the possibility that indigenous knowledge might strongly emerge online. The prevalence of antagonistic online interactions (e.g., ‘trolling’) was viewed by many Inuit as an offensive behavioral norm rooted in southern cultures, and as a particular impediment to participation in discussions.
  4. Despite these constraints, Inuit are actively pursuing opportunities to develop digital practices that strengthen their ability to share indigenous knowledge with wider audiences. They have used digital spaces to argue for more rigorous practices of consultation, for the expansion and strengthening of digital infrastructure, and for the importance of indigenous knowledge. Capacity building in the region, from the technical training of students to the funding of Inuit digital projects and infrastructure, would be greatly welcomed by many communities.

 

This project was essential in training Co-PI Young as a researcher, and directly led to the successful completion of his doctoral degree. He has also disseminated research findings through the courses that he has taught, through multiple presentations at professional conferences, and via his academic website. Young is currently working to complete an Executive Summary of the project findings to share with partner organizations, in addition to manuscripts for submission to professional journals. These findings offer lessons for understanding how vulnerable groups can better leverage digital technologies to empower themselves, and how different stakeholders might collaborate with one another and with policymakers across cultural barriers.
